abstract: Rumors that Islamic State is taking hold in Taliban stronghold of southern Afghanistan may point less to Islamic State expansion than to divisions and frustrations within Taliban; Islamic State's successes in Syria and Iraq may appeal to Taliban fighters frustrated with their stalled movement and long absence of leader Mullah Muhammad Omar, leaving Taliban fighters open to ISIS recruitment.
lead_paragraph: The long absence of the movement’s reclusive leader, Mullah Muhammad Omar, appears to be driving discontent within the ranks of the Afghan Taliban.

byline.contributor: Taimoor Shah reported from Kandahar, and Joseph Goldstein from Kabul, Afghanistan. Azam Ahmed and Ahmad Shakib contributed reporting from Kabul.
byline.original: By TAIMOOR SHAH and JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN

snippet: The long absence of the movement’s reclusive leader, Mullah Muhammad Omar, appears to be driving discontent within the ranks of the Afghan Taliban.

keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
keywords.name: organizations

headline.main: Taliban Fissures in Afghanistan Are Seen as an Opening for ISIS
headline.print_headline: Taliban Fissures in Afghanistan Are Seen as an Opening for ISIS
